images.caption: Figure 1:Overview of theImpossibleBenchframework. We start with tasks from established coding benchmarks and create impossible variants by mutating test cases to conflict with natural language specifications. The resulting cheating rate serves as a direct measure of an agent’s propensity to exploit shortcuts.

Figure 3:Cheating rates of leading models onImpossible-SWEbenchtogether with their performances on original benchmarks.Fullscaffold is used in these experiments (seeappendix˜Cfor other scaffolds). In general, we observe more capable models having higher cheating rates.

Figure 4:Cheating rates of leading models onImpossible-LiveCodeBenchtogether with their performances on original benchmarks.Minimalscaffold is used in these experiments. We observe less cheating onImpossible-LiveCodeBenchcompared toImpossible-SWEbench.

Figure 5:Classification of cheating methods onConflicting-SWEbenchfor each model, aggregated over two scaffolds. In general, OpenAI models exhibit more diverse cheating behaviors. Only1313cheating transcripts are classified for GPT-4.1 due to its low cheating rate.
Figure 6:Cheating rates of models onConflicting-LiveCodeBenchwith prompts of varying levels of guidance strictness, together with 90% confidence intervals.Minimalscaffold is used.
Figure 7:Effect of hiding tests and making tests read-only onImpossible-SWEbench.Fullscaffold is used. We revert the modified tests during scoring in the read-only setting.
Figure 8:Effect of allowing models to abort onImpossible-SWEbench.Fullscaffold is used.
Figure 10:LLM monitoring results onImpossibleBenchand open-test original benchmarks.

Figure 18:OnImpossible-SWEbench, average cheating rates over tasks and models for different task difficulty.Fullscaffold is used.
